t: Luke 7
A Centurion’s Faith
When*p he had concluded saying all this to the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum.
A centurion’s servant, who was highly valued by him, was sick and about to die.
When the centurion heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish elders to him, requesting him to come and save the life of his servant.
When they reached Jesus, they pleaded with him earnestly, saying, “He is worthy for you to grant this,
because he loves our nation and has built us a synagogue.”
Jesus*p went with them, and when he was not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to tell him, “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, since I am not worthy to have you come under my roof.
That is why I didn’t even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed.
For I too am a man placed under authority, having soldiers under my command. I say to this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and to another, ‘Come,’ and he comes; and to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.”
Jesus*p heard this and was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I*r tell*r you,*r I*r have*r not*r found*r so*r great*r a*r faith*r even*r in*r Israel.”*r
When those who had been sent returned to the house, they found the servant in good health.
A Widow’s Son Raised to Life
Afterward*p he was on his way to a town called Nain. His disciples and a large crowd were traveling with him.
Just as he neared the gate of the town, a dead man was being carried out. He was his mother’s only son, and she was a widow. A large crowd from the town was also with her.
When the Lord saw her, he had compassion on her and said, “Don’t*r weep.”*r
Then he came up and touched the open coffin, and the pallbearers stopped. And he said, “Young*r man,*r I*r tell*r you,*r get*r up!”*r
The*p dead man sat up and began to speak, and Jesus gave him to his mother.
Then fear came over everyone, and they glorified God, saying, “A great prophet has risen among us,” and “God has visited his people.”
This report about him went throughout Judea and all the vicinity.
In Praise of John the Baptist
Then*p John’s disciples told him about all these things. So John summoned two of his disciples
and sent them to the Lord, asking, “Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?”
When*p the men reached him, they said, “John the Baptist sent us to ask you, ‘Are you the one who is to come, or should we expect someone else?’”
At*p that time Jesus healed many people of diseases, afflictions, and evil spirits, and he granted sight to many blind people.

He replied to them, “Go*r and*r report*r to*r John*r what*r you*r have*r seen*r and*r heard:*r The*r blind*r receive*r their*r sight,*r the*r lame*r walk,*r those*r with*r leprosy*r are*r cleansed,*r the*r deaf*r hear,*r the*r dead*r are*r raised,*r and*r the*r poor*r are*r told*r the*r good*r news,*r
and*r blessed*r is*r the*r one*r who*r isn’t*r offended*r by*r me.”*r
After*p John’s messengers left, he began to speak to the crowds about John: “What*r did*r you*r go*r out*r into*r the*r wilderness*r to*r see?*r A*r reed*r swaying*r in*r the*r wind?*r
What*r then*r did*r you*r go*r out*r to*r see?*r A*r man*r dressed*r in*r soft*r clothes?*r See,*r those*r who*r are*r splendidly*r dressed*r and*r live*r in*r luxury*r are*r in*r royal*r palaces.*r
What*r then*r did*r you*r go*r out*r to*r see?*r A*r prophet?*r Yes,*r I*r tell*r you,*r and*r more*r than*r a*r prophet.*r
This*r is*r the*r one*r about*r whom*r it*r is*r written:*r See,*irpn I*ir am*ir sending*ir my*ir messenger*ir ahead*irln of*ir you;*ir he*irln will*ir prepare*ir your*ir way*ir before*ir you.*ir
I*rp tell*r you,*r among*r those*r born*r of*r women*r no*r one*r is*r greater*r than*r John,*r but*r the*r least*r in*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r greater*r than*r he.”*r
(And*p when all the people, including the tax collectors, heard this, they acknowledged God’s way of righteousness, because they had been baptized with John’s baptism.
But since the Pharisees and experts in the law had not been baptized by him, they rejected the plan of God for themselves.)
An Unresponsive Generation
“To*rp what*r then*r should*r I*r compare*r the*r people*r of*r this*r generation,*r and*r what*r are*r they*r like?*r

They*r are*r like*r children*r sitting*r in*r the*r marketplace*r and*r calling*r to*r each*r other:*r We*rpn played*r the*r flute*r for*r you,*r but*rln you*r didn’t*r dance;*r we*rln sang*r a*r lament,*r but*rln you*r didn’t*r weep!*r
For*rp John*r the*r Baptist*r did*r not*r come*r eating*r bread*r or*r drinking*r wine,*r and*r you*r say,*r ‘He*r has*r a*r demon!’*r
The*r Son*r of*r Man*r has*r come*r eating*r and*r drinking,*r and*r you*r say,*r ‘Look,*r a*r glutton*r and*r a*r drunkard,*r a*r friend*r of*r tax*r collectors*r and*r sinners!’*r
Yet*r wisdom*r is*r vindicated*r by*r all*r her*r children.”*r
Much Forgiveness, Much Love
Then*p one of the Pharisees invited him to eat with him. He entered the Pharisee’s house and reclined at the table.
And a woman in the town who was a sinner found out that Jesus was reclining at the table in the Pharisee’s house. She brought an alabaster jar of perfume
and stood behind him at his feet, weeping, and began to wash his feet with her tears. She wiped his feet with her hair, kissing them and anointing them with the perfume.
When*p the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, “This man, if he were a prophet, would know who and what kind of woman this is who is touching him - she’s a sinner!”
Jesus*p replied to him, “Simon,*r I*r have*r something*r to*r say*r to*r you.”*r He*p said, “Say it, teacher.”
“A*rp creditor*r had*r two*r debtors.*r One*r owed*r five*r hundred*r denarii,*r and*r the*r other*r fifty.*r
Since*r they*r could*r not*r pay*r it*r back,*r he*r graciously*r forgave*r them*r both.*r So,*r which*r of*r them*r will*r love*r him*r more?”*r
Simon*p answered, “I suppose the one he forgave more.” “You*rp have*r judged*r correctly,”*r he told him.

Turning to the woman, he said to Simon, “Do*r you*r see*r this*r woman?*r I*r entered*r your*r house;*r you*r gave*r me*r no*r water*r for*r my*r feet,*r but*r she,*r with*r her*r tears,*r has*r washed*r my*r feet*r and*r wiped*r them*r with*r her*r hair.*r
You*r gave*r me*r no*r kiss,*r but*r she*r hasn’t*r stopped*r kissing*r my*r feet*r since*r I*r came*r in.*r
You*r didn’t*r anoint*r my*r head*r with*r olive*r oil,*r but*r she*r has*r anointed*r my*r feet*r with*r perfume.*r
Therefore*r I*r tell*r you,*r her*r many*r sins*r have*r been*r forgiven;*r that’s*r why*r she*r loved*r much.*r But*r the*r one*r who*r is*r forgiven*r little,*r loves*r little.”*r
Then he said to her, “Your*r sins*r are*r forgiven.”*r
Those*p who were at the table with him began to say among themselves, “Who is this man who even forgives sins?”
And*p he said to the woman, “Your*r faith*r has*r saved*r you.*r Go*r in*r peace.”*r
